text: The Risk-Reversal Premium Blair Hull* Euan Sinclair** First Draft: 12/01/2020 This Draft: 09/01/2021 Abstract We study the risk-reversal premium, where out-of-the-money puts are over-priced relative to out-of- the-money calls. This effect is driven by investorsâ€™ utility preferences which lead them to over-pay for the risk reduction benefits of long puts instead of valuing options on the basis of expected returns. Investors can exploit this implied skewness premium by trading standard, exchange-traded index options. We also show that including risk-reversals in an equity portfolio creates a better portfolio (as measured by Sharpe ratio) compared to a pure index position. JEL Classification Numbers: G00, G1, G11, G13. Keywords: Volatility, Skewness, Options, Diversification, Alternative Beta, Portfolio Management. * Blair Hull founded Hull Trading Company in 1985 and served as the firmâ€™s chairman and chief executive officer before selling it to Goldman Sachs in 1999. Hull is now founder and chairman of Hull Tactical Asset Allocation, LLC, a registered investment advisor and operator of the actively managed equity ETF, HTUS. **Euan Sinclair, PhD, is a quantitative derivatives trader at Hull Tactical Asset Allocation, LLC. text: Understanding volatility is important to investors. Not only is volatility a source of risk, but it is now traded as an asset class. Researchers have reached a consensus that implied volatility is generally overpriced and that short positions in variance, either through swaps or delta-hedged options, produce positive returns. However, far less is understood about what specific characteristics of implied volatility leads to these returns and how these characteristics relate to each other. In this note we examine a particular implied volatility strategy: the risk-reversal. We document the profits from trading risk-reversals, selling an out-of-the-money put and buying an out-of-the-money call with the same time to expiry. Conceptually, we can think of this risk-reversal premium as analogous to the beta of a stock, which quantifies the relationship between the stockâ€™s returns and those of the broad market. The idea of beta was proposed in the Capital Asset Pricing Model (Treynor, 1962, Sharpe, 1964, Lintner, 1965 and Mossin, 1966)) in the 1960â€™s but since then the concept has been extended to various factors. The first to do this were Fama and French (1993) with their three-factor model. In addition to the overall market beta, this model included value and size factors. Similarly, we view the risk-reversal premium as a sub- factor of the well documented variance risk premium: the tendency of implied variance to be higher than the subsequent realized variance. Just as an equity portfolio can benefit from exposure to smart equity beta factors, a volatility portfolio will benefit from including each of these variance premia. The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In Section Two, we discuss the variance risk premium and the risk-reversal premium. In Section Three, we show that delta-hedged risk-reversal positions, where we are short puts and long calls, generate positive returns for several broad equity index ETFs. In Section Four we show that a portfolio that holds short risk-reversals outperforms pure index portfolios in a mean-variance sense. Section Five suggests further work and concludes. 2. Variance, Straddles and Risk-Reversals The variance risk premium is the phenomenon that implied variance tends to over-estimate future realized variance. Early proposals to monetize this effect were Dupire (1993) and Neuberger (1990) who wrote about profiting from the replicated implied variance from option strips (Breeden and Litzenberger, 1978). Other work along this line was done by Carr and Madan (1998), Demeterfi, Derman, Kamal and Zou (1999) and Britten-Jones and Neuberger (2000). Empirical studies were carried out by Wu (2011), using the returns of traded variance swaps, and by Carr and Wu (2009b), using synthetic variance swaps. There are several reasons for this phenomenon. The effect can be re-expressed as an implied skewness premium (Kozhan et al, 2011) or an implied correlation premium (Driessen et al, 2009), but these are re- statements of the phenomenon rather than explanations. Broadly, both of these explanations say that investor demand for options exceeds supply. Most investors are long equities and would use options for downside protection (Between November 1996 and October 2019 the ratio of index puts to index calls traded on the CBOE averages 1.20.). This directly increases out-of-the-money put prices (Garleanu et al, 2005), which in turn increases the implied volatility of other options as market-makers spread their 2 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3968542

text: The short straddle strategy directly trades the implied volatility of the options against the subsequent realized volatility of the underlying. If implied volatility is higher than the realized volatility, on average a short straddle will be profitable (This effect is only true on average due to path dependency. Even when implied is higher than realized, it is quite possible for the short straddle to lose money (Sinclair, 2013)). A number of researchers use straddle trading strategies to evaluate volatility forecasts (for example, Noh et al. (1994), Engle and Rosenberg (2000)). But straddles can also be traded with no volatility forecast, where we aim to passively collect a premium. An early discussion of how options were over- priced was in the book, â€œThe Put and Callâ€ by Leonard Higgins (Higgins, 1906, from Dotsis, 2020). The author writes how traders on the London Stock Exchange first determine a statistical fair value for options then â€œadd to the â€œaverage valueâ€ of the put and call an amount which will give a fair margin of profitâ€. That is, a variance risk premium was added. Coval and Shumway (2001) show that an at-the- money straddle position consistently produces negative returns, as does Londono, 2011. However, it is well known that underlying returns are not normally distributed, and higher order moments need to be considered when pricing options. To avoid arbitrage, the price of an option is equal to its discounted expected payoff over the risk-neutral distribution. However, a specific risk-neutral distribution needs to be chosen. The Black-Scholes-Merton (BSM) model assumes the underlying price has a lognormal distribution, but this is not an accurate description of the real market. Early studies to show that the physical distribution was not lognormal were Osborne (1959) and Mandelbrot (1963). And Mandelbrot cited the much earlier work of Mitchell (1915), Oliver (1926) and Mills (1927). This research has been corroborated many times since. Even allowing for the fact that the risk-neutral distribution and physical distribution are different, the lognormal is clearly an inappropriate choice. Many alternative stochastic processes for the underlying price have been proposed, which would lead to different, more realistic, risk-neutral distributions (see for example, Cox and Ross (1976), Bates (1991), Hull and White (1987)). In general, traders have taken a different approach. They price options using the BSM model (or a suitable modification to account for any early exercise features) but use a different volatility input for each strike. Volatility as a function of strike forms the implied volatility curve, smile or smirk. Breeden and Litzenberger (1978) showed that the implied risk-neutral distribution could be calculated from the implied volatility smile. Many studies have since shown that the implied risk-neutral density is more negatively skewed than the lognormal distribution. Further, the implied risk-neutral skewness is generally greater in magnitude than the subsequent realized skewness. This is not necessarily irrational and nor is it due to the options embedding an incorrect forecast of the future realized skewness. Unlike in the case of a straddle, where implied volatility dictates price and realized volatility dictates returns, the implied skew premium has very little to do with the skewness of the underlying. Further, just as with the ATM volatility premium, the implied skew premium is time varying and will sometimes trade at a discount. The expected profit from a hedged risk-reversal is mainly driven by the correlation between the underlying price and the level of volatility. Consider an investor who is short out-of-the-money puts and long out-of-the-money calls. As the underlying rises, her net vega exposure will increase. Hence, she benefits from a positive correlation between the volatility level and the underlying price. So while we could use any delta risk-reversal to calculate the skew, the 25-delta options are a good compromise between being close enough to the at-the-money strike for the quadratic parametrization to work well, and being far enough away that the absolute difference between 25-delta put and 25-delta call volatility is significant. While the profit (or loss) of a hedged risk-reversal does not depend greatly on the skewness of the underlying (refer to Equation Five), Equation 14 says that the entry price is entirely determined by the implied skewness. There have been many studies that show out-of-the-money put options are overpriced (for example, Coval and Shumway, 2001, Ait-Sahlia et al, 2001 and Bondarenko, 2014). However, risk-reversals have not been studied to the same extent. In the same way that investors utility preferences lead them to buy puts, there are also many investors who sell calls as part of a covered call strategy (REF). Finally calls are not typically bought as hedges, further lowering demand. Together, these effects create a risk- reversal premium which is distinct from the variance premium. Bergomi (2009) and Sepp (2010) presented some empirical data but both studies mainly focused on the theoretical valuation of the option strategy and the empirical study was presented as an illustration. text: We construct a hedged risk reversal using SPY options. We initiate the position by selling the 15-delta puts and buying the 15-delta calls with the expiration closest to 25 trading days until expiration. The initial hedge is to sell short 30 shares of SPY. The position is delta-hedged daily, and each week the strikes are adjusted to remain as close as possible to 15-delta. The position is closed when there are five trading days left, and a new 25-day position is entered. The account returns are calculated on the Regulation T margin required (12 CFR Â§220 â€“ Code of Federal Regulations, Title 12, Chapter II, Subchapter A, Part 220 (Credit by Brokers and Dealers)) and is normalized to an initial value of 100. Our test uses IVolatility daily end of day prices spanning the period from January the 18th, 2005 to the 31st of December, 2019. Option strikes are the listed strikes on the contemporaneous SPY price but the hedge uses a back-adjusted SPY price series to account for dividends. The sample consists of 3766 trading days. The interest rate used when calculating excess returns for the Sharpe ratio calculations is the overnight Fed funds rate from the St. Lois Federal Reserve (available at https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFF). It was assumed that all trades could be performed at the mid- price. Results without transaction costs are shown in Table One and the cumulative account value is shown in Figure One. text: While this example shows the clear existence of a premium in the delta-hedged risk-reversal, this implementation is far from what traders would do in practice (Sinclair, 2013). Common industry practice is to let the delta of a position fluctuate within a certain band and only re-hedge when those bands are crossed. In our case, whenever the net delta of the options either drops below 20 or above 40, the portfolio is rebalanced by closing the position and re-establishing with the options that are now closest to 15-delta in the same expiration. Next, we determined that the return series for the ETFs and the corresponding 15-delta risk-reversals are not drawn from the same distribution by applying a Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. In all cases, the null hypothesis that the ETF and risk-reversal returns come from the same distribution is rejected at the 0.001 level. To an investor, the important aspect of instruments being â€œdifferentâ€ is they can be combined in a diversified portfolio that is in some sense better than each individual asset. This is the case with the risk- reversals. Our choice for portfolio construction is to find the optimal number of risk-reversals to hold with 100 shares of SPY. The hedged 15-delta risk reversal consists of one risk-reversal and short 30 shares. So, when combined with 100 shares of SPY a one risk-reversal portfolio would consist of 70 shares, one short 15-delta put and long one 15-delta call. The portfolio composition was chosen to maximize the Sharpe ratio. In practice, investors could have other risk targets, possibly looking to match the volatility of the underlying ETF or to minimize drawdown. It is important to note that while the historically realized risk has been acceptable (similar to the underlying ETF), by adding the short puts, we have raised the probability and consequences of a catastrophic scenario. While some losses will be mitigated by the vega of the long calls responding to the corresponding increase in implied volatility, in the worst-case scenario when the ETF drops below the short put strike, a one-to-one portfolio will be long more delta than a pure equity position. The fact that this has not occurred in the time period used in our test, does not mean it is impossible. In practice, investors may choose to arbitrarily cap their risk-reversal exposure because of this. 5. Conclusion We have shown that selling risk-reversals on US equity ETFs has been a profitable strategy. This premium accrues to delta-hedged portfolios, so it provides a diversifying component to long equity positions. 12 Electronic copy available at: https://ssrn.com/abstract=3968542

text: Although this is to our knowledge the most comprehensive published examination of risk-reversal returns, it is still very preliminary. Most importantly, whether risk-reversals are systematically mispriced in other assets is unknown. Further, a comprehensive study of the relationship between the implied skewness premium and the variance risk premium should be carried out. Finally, the empirical results presented here could possibly be improved in practice. Just as traders wanting to harvest the variance risk premium forecast both realized and implied volatilities, the risk-reversal trade could benefit from forecasting the realized correlation between underlying and implied volatility (analogous to forecasting realized volatility), and the implied skewness expressed in Equation 14. Nonetheless, we have shown that the risk-reversal has been significantly mispriced in US equity indices and that this can be traded as a hedged, market neutral strategy or used as a component of a directional portfolio. 6.
